title: Tech advances "too slow" say ACTE buyers | Buying Business Travel
text:
0 comments Tom Newcombe Fri, 16 Oct 2015 09:09 Follow @thomasnewcombe Travel buyers have called on suppliers to speed up innovation in the industry and invest more in technology so they can provide their travellers with the tools they need.
Speaking at the ACTE conference in Paris yesterday a panel of buyers along with members of the audience spoke out at the lack of speed in which innovative products are available.
Microsoft's group manager for global meetings and travel, Georgie Farmer, said: "I do think there is innovation in the industry but not at the speed we want.
"There are challenges but also opportunities we just need the supplier to innovate."
One buyer from a multi-national company said the travel industry was stuck behind many other sectors and added: "we are still playing catch up".
"I can't give my road warriors a good enough booking app at the moment. Change is too slow and I'm asking where's the innovation from suppliers?"
However, Paul Tilstone founder and CEO at consultancy Festive Road, argued there was innovation in the industry and challenged buyers' companies to create their own technology solutions.
BCD Travel's senior VP of global client management Chris Crowley also defended suppliers. He said the industry was open to innovation and that most of it was consumer driven. "As a TMC we support 27 online booking tools, around 300 apps and have 430 different profile systems. We understand every client is different."
The panel also discussed the importance of getting "buy-in" from the executive level when trying to implement changes in travel programmes.
One buyer said: "Without c-suite support it's hard to make the changes you want. Buyers must force the issue and start having discussions with execs to gain that support."
The panel were discussing Building the next travel programme at the ACTE conference in Paris yesterday.
